Hi,
   
  My experience in a quarter-century-plus of software development and testing, most recently solely testing, is that a laissez-faire approach to the subject is what has continued the troubles that software has always had regarding quality. I'm not saying wage Holy War and convert the masses, but I think it's worth discussing!
   
  I am on this list for two reasons. One, I am getting back into Java development, and want to employ junit properly. Two, I have worked with Java developers as a tester, and have suffered the consequences of their lack of interest in junit. Yes, I have a view on the matter. But what I want to discover, from both sides of the aisle, so to speak, is the eternal question - what makes testing worthwhile to people?
   
  I am, oddly enough, a human factors guy as well. I bugged Kent Beck about how people could keep up the intensity of the XP model, and he had a great answer - the "Flow" concept put forth by Czikszentmihalyi, which is something that many successful people in many different fields are familiar with. I'm looking for something similar in the matter of testing.
   
  So what I'm looking for in these discussions, is how can we avoid the problem of avoidable bugs making it too far downstream, or in other words, producing the code that we *intend* to produce. We can test bugs out, code review might help, reuse of tested code helps, and so forth. When I am a programmer, I get my joy out of coding - how can I keep in the "flow", and yet have some faith that I am doing what I need to for the cause of quality, and producing my intended result?
   
  Now if that isn't a theological contemplation, I don't know what is!
   
  Dave
  

"J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
          Pat Farrell wrote:

> The signal to noise ratio of this mailing list is very low.
> Some people believe in testing, some don't. There is zero chance that
> minds will be changed.
> 
> JUnit is a tool. I like what it does. I'd like to learn better ways to
> use it to make my life as a developer better. It is hard to find any
> useful information between all the rants.
> 
> Purity tests and arguments about them are noise.
> IMHO, YMMV, etc.

Pat, I respect your opinion, but when you complain about the noise on 
such a low-traffic list, I find it difficult to take you seriously. So 
many of the questions on this list are from beginners too lazy to use 
Google that, as a balance, I like these discussions (not theological 
rants, by the way--no need to insult--I, for one, am pragmatic in my 
discussion, so would that be applied theology?).

I understand that that's not what you want to read, and I'm sorry you're 
not getting what you want from the list right now. One option you have 
is to start a thread and ask the questions you want answered. You can 
also ignore the threads you don't want to read. You can also leave the 
list, although I hope you won't.

JUnit is a design tool, and so naturally we will tend to discuss how 
JUnit tests affect our design. I think that's both on topic for this 
list and important to let flower.

JUnit is a testing tool, and so naturally we will tend to discuss how 
much we should and shouldn't test our code. I think that's both on topic 
for this list and important to let flower.

I really don't think we have let this get to the point of navel-gazing, 
but you might disagree with that. I might be too close to the 
discussions to remain objective in this regard.

If we continue to mark such threads with subject lines that make it 
clear you're not interested in them, would that help you find what you 
want from this list?
